üì® Task: Write a tutorial explaining how to construct an interesting data visualization of the Palmer Penguins data set.

üõë BEFORE STARTING üõë

Make sure to import these libraries used: Plotly, Pandas, Numpy, Seaborn

üêß Step 1: Import palmer_penguins CSV to the environment.

import pandas as pd
url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pic16b-ucla/24W/main/datasets/palmer_penguins.csv"
penguins = pd.read_csv(url)

üêß Step 2: Perform some data cleaning steps.

penguins.info()

# cleaning the data
penguins.isnull().sum()

# filling nan values with 0
penguins.fillna(0)
Some methods I used:
.info()
Presents the information of each column and the amount of entries within each column.
.isnull().sum()
Takes the sum of each column that has a NaN value.

üêß Step 3: Use Plotly to create nicer looking graphs.

‚ÄúPlotly‚Äôs Python graphing library makes interactive, publication-quality graphs. Examples of how to make line plots, scatter plots, area charts, bar charts, error bars, box plots, histograms, heatmaps, subplots, multiple-axes, polar charts, and bubble charts.‚Äù ‚Äì From Plotly Website

‚òÉÔ∏è I decided to use plotly because of its ability to create complex but informational graphs, charts, plots easily. I utilized the scatterplot code from their documentation to create the plot.

from plotly import express as px

# create a scatter plot
fig = px.scatter(data_frame = penguins, x = 'Body Mass (g)', y = 'Flipper Length (mm)', color = "Species",
                 width = 1000, height = 600, title = "Flipper Length (mm) and Body Mass (g) for Penguin Species")

fig.update_layout(margin={"r":0, "t":50, "l":0, "b":0})

#show the plot
fig.show()

‚òÉÔ∏è I chose to represent the flipper length (mm) and body mass (g) for all penguin species that were present in the data set.
